Literature Review: Plant diseases pose a significant threat to global food security and agricultural sustainability. As traditional pesticides face increasing restrictions due to environmental and health concerns, there is a growing need for novel, eco-friendly approaches to plant disease control. Functional peptides have emerged as promising candidates for biopesticides, offering unique mechanisms of action against a wide range of plant pathogens. This literature review explores the current state of research on functional peptides for plant disease control, their sources, production methods, and challenges in their development and application.Functional peptides are short chains of amino acids that exhibit biological activity against plant pathogens. These peptides can be derived from natural sources or synthesized artificially to mimic or enhance the properties of naturally occurring compounds. The interest in functional peptides for plant disease control has grown significantly in recent years, driven by the need for sustainable alternatives to conventional pesticides.One of the key advantages of functional peptides is their diverse mechanisms of action against plant pathogens. Montesinos et al. (2012) reviewed the antimicrobial activities of various peptides, highlighting their ability to target multiple cellular processes in pathogens, including membrane disruption, inhibition of cell wall synthesis, and interference with DNA replication. This multi-target approach makes functional peptides less likely to induce resistance in pathogen populations compared to single-site-of-action pesticides.The efficacy of functional peptides against a broad spectrum of plant pathogens has been demonstrated in numerous studies. For instance, Keymanesh et al. (2009) reported on the antifungal properties of defensins, a class of cysteine-rich peptides found in plants. These peptides showed significant inhibitory effects against various fungal pathogens, including Fusarium oxysporum and Botrytis cinerea. Similarly, Zeitler et al. (2013) investigated the antibacterial activity of synthetic peptides against Xanthomonas campestris, a major bacterial pathogen affecting cruciferous crops.The sources of functional peptides for plant disease control are diverse. Many peptides are isolated from living organisms, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. Nawrot et al. (2014) reviewed plant-derived peptides with antimicrobial properties, emphasizing their potential as natural biopesticides. Additionally, advances in peptide synthesis and biotechnology have enabled the production of synthetic analogs and novel peptides with enhanced stability and efficacy.Large-scale production of functional peptides is crucial for their commercial viability as biopesticides. Ingham and Moore (2007) discussed various production methods, including chemical synthesis, recombinant DNA technology, and enzymatic approaches. While chemical synthesis offers flexibility in peptide design, biotechnological platforms using microbial fermentation have shown promise for cost-effective, large-scale production.Despite their potential, the development of functional peptides as commercial biopesticides faces several challenges. Stability in the plant environment is a primary concern, as peptides are susceptible to degradation by proteases and environmental factors. Marcos et al. (2008) explored strategies to enhance peptide stability, including the use of D-amino acids and cyclization techniques. Formulation development is another critical aspect, as suitable carriers and delivery systems are needed to protect peptides and ensure their efficacy in field conditions.Regulatory considerations also play a significant role in the commercialization of peptide-based biopesticides. Montesinos and Bardají (2008) discussed the regulatory framework for biopesticides in the European Union and the United States, highlighting the need for comprehensive toxicological and environmental impact assessments. The high cost of production remains a challenge for the widespread adoption of peptide-based products in agriculture.Recent advancements in peptide engineering and production technologies have led to increased interest in functional peptides for plant disease control. Makovitzki et al. (2007) reported on the development of ultrashort antimicrobial peptides with broad-spectrum activity against plant pathogens, demonstrating the potential for designing highly effective, minimalist peptides. Furthermore, Badosa et al. (2013) explored the use of peptide libraries and high-throughput screening methods to identify novel peptides with enhanced antimicrobial properties.As research in this field progresses, the integration of functional peptides into integrated pest management strategies is becoming more feasible. Rebollar-Alviter et al. (2020) discussed the potential of combining peptide-based biopesticides with other control methods, such as biological control agents and resistant plant varieties, to achieve more sustainable and effective disease management.In conclusion, functional peptides represent a promising avenue for the development of novel biopesticides for plant disease control. Their diverse mechanisms of action, broad-spectrum efficacy, and potential for sustainable production make them attractive alternatives to conventional pesticides. However, further research is needed to address challenges related to stability, formulation, and cost-effective production. As the field advances, it is expected that functional peptides will play an increasingly important role in sustainable agriculture and food security.
